Regina Elisabeta Bucharest 030018 Romania In this study, molybdenum doped iron cobaltite and cobalt ferrite catalysts were prepared by coprecipitation, and their structural, morphological, and optical, properties were evaluated by XRD, BET, SEM, FTIR, Raman, XPS and UV–VIS techniques. Their catalytic behavior evaluated in the malic acid oxidative decarboxylation reaction underlined the importance of the incorporation of Mo into the structure of iron cobaltite and cobalt ferrite catalysts. The catalysts with the highest molybdenum content forming cobaltite and iron molybdate phases showed better activity, with cobaltite-based catalysts being more active than ferrite-based ones. Graphical Abstract Correlation between malic acid conversion, pyruvic acid yield and phases composition Keywords Cobalt ferrite Iron cobaltite Malic acid Pyruvic acid Oxidative decarboxylation Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction The spinel-type oxides based on cobalt and iron represent an excellent platform from the point of view of the solid, crystallographic, and structural state. The physical and chemical properties of these oxides often differ from crystalline to amorphous ones. The synthesis of these oxides with the desired structure and morphology is of great interest, due to their superior properties, as well as their application in many fields, including solar cells, drug delivery, memory devices for computers, super capacitors for lithium batteries [1–3], as photocatalyst due to their exceptional electrochemical behavior and interaction between Fe and Co [4]. However, very few studies were assigned to their catalytic activity in organic reactions such as Knoevenagel condensation reaction [5], oxidation of cyclohexane, and decomposition of methanol [6,7]. Over the years, cobalt and iron oxides substituted with molybdenum were investigated to understand how the distribution of molybdenum cations influences the physical and chemical properties [8,9]. Their specific roles and effectiveness as catalysts depend on factors like their nanostructure, surface area, crystallographic orientation, and composition, which can be tailored by using a specific preparation method. Therefore, several methods were used for the synthesis of these catalysts, among them solid-state reaction [3], sonochemical technique [10], hydrothermal method [11], solution combustion [12], and sol-gel method [13,14]. These materials often exhibit good stability and durability under harsh reaction conditions, making them suitable for catalytic processes that involve high temperatures or corrosive environments. Mo-based catalysts have been studied extensively for their catalytic properties in various oxidation reactions [15]. They can act as active sites for the oxidation of organic molecules due to their ability to undergo redox cycles, enabling the transfer of oxygen atoms to the substrate. Malic acid oxidative decarboxylation to pyruvic acid is an important process, considering the multifaceted role of pyruvic acid and its significance in both fundamental biological processes and various industrial applications, contributing to energy production, cellular function, and diverse synthetic processes. For instance, pyruvic acid is used in various synthetic processes to produce compounds like ethyl lactate (used in food and fragrance industries), as well as pharmaceuticals, flavoring agents, and chemical intermediates. The reaction involves decarboxylation and dehydrogenation of malic acid, leading to the formation of pyruvic acid (see Scheme 1). Transition metal-based catalysts, such as supported metal catalysts or metal oxides, have been studied for oxidative decarboxylation processes. For instance, catalysts containing metals like palladium, platinum, ruthenium, or other transition metals supported on materials like carbon, silica, or metal oxides, have shown catalytic activity in related carboxylic acid decarboxylation reactions [16]. In the current work, we have partially substituted cobalt cations from iron cobaltite, FeCo2O4, and, iron cations from cobalt ferrite, CoFe2O4, with molybdenum cations, respectively. The replacement of M3+ cations (Co, Fe) with Mo6+ species should introduce electron doping and significantly impact its electrical and catalytic properties and can induce a possible increase of M2+ cations in tetrahedral centers [8]. We expect that such modifications in the distribution and occupancy of metal cations will influence the material's catalytic and electronic properties. Therefore, the impact of Mo introduction in iron cobaltite and cobalt ferrite catalysts on their structural, chemical, and catalytic properties was investigated in malic acid oxidative decarboxylation to pyruvic acid. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation In the synthesis of FeCo2–2xMoxO4 and CoFe2–2xMoxO4 with different molybdenum contents (x= 0.15; 0.2; 0.3) the coprecipitation method has been used. Co(NO3)2·6H2O (AGR ACS Labbox), Fe(NO3)3·9H2O (AGR ACS Labbox) and (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O (Fluka Analytical) were dissolved separately in distilled water. The solutions containing the iron and cobalt precursors were mixed and kept under stirring for 30 min. Then, the ammonium molybdate solution was added dropwise, while stirring continuously for another 30 min. To achieve the precipitation and adjust the pH value at 8, an ammonia solution, NH4OH (AGR ACS Labbox) was added dropwise while stirring. The precipitates obtained were filtered, washed several times with distilled water, and dried at a temperature of 100 °C for 24 h. The solids were grounded in an agate mortar until a fine powder was obtained, which was then calcined in air at 500 °C for 4 h. The final catalysts were named as follows: FeCoMo1 (FeCo1.7Mo0.15O4), FeCoMo2 (FeCo1.6Mo0.2O4), FeCoMo3 (FeCo1.4Mo0.3O4) and CoFeMo1 (CoFe1.7Mo0.15O4), CoFeMo2 (CoFe1.6Mo0.2O4), CoFeMo3 (CoFe1.4Mo0.3O4), respectively. 2.2 Catalysts characterization The XRD patterns of powders were achieved using a Bruker-AXS D8 Advance diffractometer (Bruker Corporation, Billerica, MA, USA) equipped with a LynxEye 1D type detector, using a Cu-Kα (0.1541 nm) radiation, with the angular range of 10–80°. The surface area and pore size of samples were calculated after performing nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms at −196 °C using a Micromeritics 3FLEX surface area and porosity analyser. The samples were degassed before analysis at 200 °C for 5 h in nitrogen. The specific surface area (SBET) of the samples was estimated by using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) model. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) were performed to investigate the morphology and composition of the samples, using a Zeiss EVO 50 XVP scanning electron microscope equipped with a Quantax Bruker 200 system. The UV–Vis diffuse reflectance spectra were recorded using a Jasco V-650 spectrometer fitted with a D2/WI light source, built-in PMT detector and a JSV-9222 integrating sphere. The scan speed was 1000 nm/min, on an interval of 0.5 nm, in the wavelength range of 200–800 nm. FTIR spectroscopy was acquired both in ATR and DRIFT using a Jasco FT/IR 4700 type A infrared spectrometer, equipped with a TGS detector. The resolution was 4 cm−1 and the scanning speed was 2 mm/s. XPS data were recorded using a Kratos Ultra DLD Setup (Kratos Analytical Ltd., Manchester, UK), with an Al K (1486.74 eV) radiation source and a monochromated X-ray source with a total power of 300 W. The Raman spectra were obtained within the frequency range of 100–1000 cm–1 at ambient temperature using a Horiba Jobin Yvon LabRAM HR Evolution spectrometer. The spectrometer was fitted with a Sincerity CCD Peltier-cooled detector capable of reaching temperatures as low as −60 °C. The spectra were obtained by taking the average of five accumulations of laser exposure lasting 30 seconds each. The laser used was an air-cooled He-Ne laser emitting radiation at a wavelength of 633 nm. To address the degradation of the samples, a neutral density filter was employed to regulate the laser output at a power level of 10 mW, utilizing only 25 % of its total power. 2.3 Catalytic tests Malic acid oxidative decarboxylation has been carried out in a two-necked flat-bottom flask (25 cm3). The flask was placed on a heated magnetic stirrer (Fisher Scientific Isotemp) surrounded by a thermal jacket. The reaction was carried out using a solution of 2 % malic acid in water, under stirring, with a speed of 400 rpm, using as oxidant air (20 mLmin–1), at a temperature of 50 °C. The amount of the catalyst added in each reaction was 50 mg. The reaction products were analyzed at regular time intervals (30 min), by taking aliquots from the solution. A gas-chromatograph (Thermo-Quest GC K072320) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) has been used for this purpose. The conversion of malic acid, selectivity and yield in products were expressed as follow: M a l i c a c i d c o n v e r s i o n = m o l e s o f m a l i c a c i d c o n v e r t e d m o l e s o f m a l i c a c i d int r o d u c e d 100 Products s e l e c t i v i t y = m o l e s o f m a l i c a c i d c o n v e r t e d i n p r o d u c t " x " m o l e s o f m a l i c a c i d c o n v e r t e d 100 Products y i e l d = m o l e s o f m a l i c a c i d c o n v e r t e d i n p r o d u c t " x " m o l e s o f m a l i c a c i d introduced 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization Fig. 1 a and Fig. 1 b show the powder XRD patterns of FeCo2–2xMoxO4 and CoFe2–2xMoxO4 series, respectively. Irrespective of the Mo content, FeCoMo and CoFeMo patterns indicated lines belonging to (111), (220), (311), (400), (511) and (440) reflection planes indexed to the cubic lattice of FeCo2O4 and CoFe2O4, respectively, which agrees with literature (JCPDS No. 00–066–0244; JCPDS No. 04–0850) [17,18]. In particular, FeCo2–2xMoxO4 samples present a line at 10.9⁰ (110) and an intense line at 26.5° attributed to the reflection of the (220) plane of β-FeMoO4 phase (JCPDS No 22-0628) [19] which is better expressed for the sample containing the highest Mo loading. In CoFe2–2xMoxO4 samples, low intensity peaks indexed at 15.4° (200) and 25° (002) correspond to monoclinic structure of β-CoMoO4 (JCPDS No 021-0868, see inset Fig. 1 b) [20]. The possible nanocrystalline nature of samples has been indicated by the broad diffraction peaks [21]. The broadening of peaks and lattice strain were evaluated from XRD patterns, the microstrain being expressed with the formula: (1) ε = β hkl 4 tan θ where ε represents the microstrain, βhkl is FWHM in radian, while θ is the angle of diffraction. The utilization of the Williamson-Hall (W-H) analysis can be employed to elucidate the impact of microstrain and particle size on the broadening of peaks. This analytical approach offers a more precise estimation of crystallite size compared to the Scherrer analysis. Full width at half maximum (FWHM) is expressed as the sum between size and microstrain: (2) βhkl = βsize + βstrain (3) β hkl = K λ D cos θ + 4 ε tan θ which can be rearranged as follow: (4) β hkl cos θ = K λ D + 4 ε sin θ The microstrain and crystallite size respectively could be estimated by the representation of βhklcosθ as a function of 4sinθ. The size of the crystallite was estimated from a linear fit interception with Y-axis, while the microstrain was estimated from the slope ( Table 1 and Fig. 2). Many authors [22,23] reported that a positive slope indicates an expansion of the lattice, while a negative slope is an indication of a compression of the lattice [24,25]. In our particular scenario, it is observed that the slope of the samples is positive. However, it is noteworthy that the line representing the second sample from each series is displaced towards the right in comparison to the line representing the first sample of each series. This displacement suggests the presence of compressive strain. Conversely, the line representing the last sample in each series is pushed towards the left, suggesting the existence of tensile strain. Various imperfections such as stacking faults and dislocation arrays, have been known to generate size widening in crystals. Also, the existence of imperfections such as vacancies, dislocations, and interstitials induce lattice strain cannot be excluded. The evaluation of dislocation density necessitates the prior measurement of the lattice constant. In this regard, the Nelson-Riley plot serves as a valuable analytical tool. Dislocation density (δ) [26] can be calculated with the formula: (5) δ = 1 / D 2 where a is lattice parameter that was calculated using formula: (6) a = d ⋅ h 2 + k 2 + l 2 and d is spacing between two planes calculated as follow: (7) d = n ⋅ λ 2 ⋅ sin θ X-ray density was calculated using formula: (8) ρ x = 8 M N A ⋅ a 3 where: M is the molecular weight of sample, NA is the Avogadro number and 8 is the number of molecules per unit cell. In the Nelson-Riley plot, the lattice constant values of different planes versus the error function, has been represented in Fig. 3, and the apparent lattice constant can be determined from the Nelson- Riley plot intercept with Y axis. The error function F (θ) is given by: (9) F ( θ ) = [ ( cos 2 θ + sin θ ) ] + ( cos 2 θ θ ) 2 The increase in the content of molybdenum leads to an observed rise in both dislocation density and microstrains, which can be attributed to an increase in the number of oxygen vacancies. Mo6+ cations, with a radius of 0.55 Å, enter in tetrahedral centers, while, in order to maintain neutrality, a part of Fe3+ cations (rFe3+ = 0.65 Å) and Co3+ (rCo3+ = 0.67 Å) are transformed in Fe2+ (rFe2+ = 0.77 Å) and Co2+ (rCo2+ = 0.72 Å), which contributes to a decrease in the cation-anion distance (tetrahedral) and to a decrease in the lattice parameter. To relax the strain, a part of Fe2+ and Co2+ cations from the tetrahedral centers, will migrate to the octahedral centers. The expansion of the network observed in the last catalyst of each series can be attributed to the substitution of cobalt or iron ions in the octahedral centers with molybdenum ions. On the other hand, the decrease in lattice parameter observed in the second catalyst of each series can be attributed to the presence of a distorted or secondary phase, where the molybdenum ions do not substitute cobalt and iron ions in the cubic structure [3]. The textural parameters of all studied samples are summarized in Table 1. The surface area calculated using the BET formalism for FeCoMox samples is between 46 and 48 m2g–1, indicating that the introduction of Mo did not affect the textural properties, while for CoFeMox samples the BET surface area is a little higher with values between 61 and 93 m2g–1. The isothermal N2 adsorption-desorption plots, shown in Fig. 4, have isotherms of type IV shape, with H3 type hysteresis loops, hysteresis behavior being observed at higher relative pressure, while the pore sizes are mainly distributing between 5 and 11 nm, indicating the presence of mesopores in all materials. The SEM images of samples with various concentrations of molybdenum are depicted in Fig. 5 and show large and irregular agglomerate particles. Additionally, the EDS technique was used to determine the primary composition and quantify a particular area of interest. The atomic % for each element present in our samples is listed in Table 2. The presence of an excess of iron was noted for all samples. The chemical formula using the elemental composition (Fe, Co, Mo) of all prepared samples is given in Table 3. The ATR-FTIR spectroscopy was employed to examine the structural characteristics of the samples and determine the distribution of cations inside octahedral or tetrahedral sites and the IR spectra are shown in Fig. 6. The peak at 1635 cm–1 is associated with O–H bending vibration of water molecules [27]. The stretching vibrations of distorted tetrahedral MoO4 units are located in the 700–900 cm–1 region, with the bands at 810 cm–1 and 715 cm–1 assigned to υ1 and υ3 vibrational modes [28]. The peak located at 1070 cm–1 is associated to bending mode of Mo–OH bonds [29]. The observed peaks at 500 cm–1 and 595 cm–1 could be attributed to the Me–O stretching vibration of FeCo2O4 or CoFe2O4 spinel [4]. On the other hand, the band at a lower frequency of 440 cm–1 can be attributed to a combination of the υ4 and υ5 vibrations of MoO with the υ3 vibration of CoO6 from the CoMoO4 structure, as well as the interaction between MoO and FeO6 from FeMoO4 [30]. UV-Vis spectra of all synthesized samples ( Fig. 7) present the absorption bands at 240, 335 and 380 nm, respectively. The absorption bands observed at a wavelength of 240 nm are attributed to molybdenum species that are in a tetrahedral coordination arrangement, existing in an isolated state [31]. On the other hand, the absorption region at 335 nm is ascribed to molybdenum species that are either in an octahedral geometry or in a connected state where tetrahedral and octahedral molybdenum species are linked together [32–34]. The optical direct band gap has been obtained from the absorption data with the relationship of (αhν)2 = A(hν − Eg), where A is a constant, α represents the absorption coefficient, hν is the energy of photon and Eg represents the optical band gap, respectively. The band gap energy values were determined to be 3.27, 3.25, and 3.18 eV for samples denoted as FeCoMo1, FeCoMo2 and FeCoMo3, respectively, while the samples denoted as CoFeMo1 CoFeMo2, and CoFeMo3 exhibited band gap energy values of 3.36, 3.31, and 3.20 eV, respectively. The substitution of Co and Fe, respectively, by Mo might create localized regions with different electronic configurations, causing variations in the band gap energies, even leading to the observation of two distinct Eg values (see Fig. 7). The Urbach energy is calculated with the equation: α = α 0 exp h ν / E u where Eu is the Urbach energy [35,36]. The Urbach energy is determined by plotting lnα against hν. The Eu value is given by the reciprocal of slope of the linear portion, below optical band gap. The increase in Urbach energy values with molybdenum loading increases and respectively a decrease in band gap energy, Eg indicates the presence of a large number of oxygen vacancies [37,38]. Considering the Urbach energy values and XRD data, a good correlation between Eu and crystallite size has been observed, an increase in Eu value indicates a decrease in crystallite size [39]. DRIFT spectra before and after malic acid conversion are shown in Fig. 8. In the fingerprint region, a slight modification of structure composition for the used catalyst in each series has been observed. The bands located at 1460 and 1120 cm−1 correspond to deformation vibrations of −CH2− and −CH−OH, respectively. The signal at around 1760 cm−1 is assigned to stretching vibration of carbonyl groups (νCO) and at around 1310 cm−1 to vibration of νC−O indicating the presence of the reaction products on the surface of the catalyst. The stretching vibration of carboxylic −OH gives signal at around 3600 cm−1 for the tested sample. Fig. 9 shows the Raman spectra of the FeCoMox and CoFeMox catalysts synthesized in this study. In the case of CoFeMox samples, the Raman spectra exhibit consistent bands regardless of the Mo content present in the materials. However, for the FeCoMox samples, the situation appears to differ. Thus, the Raman spectrum of FeCoMo1 sample exhibits a notable presence of several peak maxima at specific wavenumbers, namely 189, 212, 246, 272, 294, 347, 467, 508, 580, 609, 667, 794 and 922 cm−1. Considering the prevalence of FeCo2O4 as the primary phase identified through XRD analysis and drawing upon existing literature, it can be inferred that the frequencies falling within the range of 600–700 cm−1 can be ascribed to the A1 g symmetry. This particular symmetry corresponds to the symmetric stretching of an oxygen atom in relation to the metal ion situated within the tetrahedral void [21,40]. This specific vibrational mode, popularly known as the tetrahedral breath mode, solely encompasses the displacement of oxygen atoms. Consequently, the band observed at a wavenumber of 667 cm−1 can be attributed to the presence of the cubic spinel-type structure of FeCo2O4. Additionally, the identification of an extra mode referred to as the A1 g mode at 609 cm−1 is a distinguishing trait of both inverse and mixed spinel compounds. In contrast, the phonon modes seen at frequencies lower than 600 cm−1, namely the Eg mode at 347 cm–1 and the three T2 g modes at 508, 467, and 189 cm–1, are attributed to the symmetric and antisymmetric bending of oxygen atoms within M–O links located in octahedral voids. The presence of α-Fe2O3, Fe3O4, and FeMoO4 on the surface of the FeCoMo1 sample contributes to its heterogeneity, as evidenced by the detection of bands at specific wavenumbers (212, 246, 272, 580, 794, and 922 cm–1). Therefore, the band observed at a wavenumber of 246 cm–1 can be ascribed to the Eg mode of α-Fe2O3, whereas the bands observed at wavenumbers of 212 cm–1, 272 cm–1, and 580 cm–1 are indicative of Fe3O4. The same bands were observed also in CoFeMox samples, indicating the presence of Fe3O4 also in these samples. Finally, the prominent peaks observed at wavenumbers 794 and 922 cm–1 were attributed to the stretching vibrations of the MoO bonds in FeMoO4. As the concentration of Mo increases, the characteristics of the Raman spectra begin to undergo alterations. In the case of the FeCoMo3 sample, the bands associated with the presence of α-Fe2O3, Fe3O4, and FeMoO4 are clearly discernible. However, this phenomenon is not detected in the FeCoMo2 sample, as these bands are significantly obscured. Furthermore, in both instances, in addition to the bands associated with the presence of the FeCo2O4 spinel phase, a noticeable shift of the band originally positioned at 580 cm–1 towards higher frequencies was observed (specifically, 585 cm–1 and 600 cm–1 for the FeCoMo3 and FeCoMo2 samples, respectively), all these bands being assigned to Fe3O4. Additionally, a new band emerged at 294 cm–1 in the FeCoMo2 sample, that was assigned to the Eg mode of α-Fe2O3 [41]. Fig. 10 displays the high-resolution XP spectra of O 1 s, Fe 2p, Co 2p and Mo 3d for all prepared samples. Deconvolution of O 1 s spectra shows for all samples the presence of two peaks: one at 530.1 eV, corresponding to lattice oxygen, and another at 531.3 eV, that could be associated with hydroxyl groups, but also with defective oxides (∼22 % in all samples) [42]. Fe 2p signal overlaps the auger lines of Co, but some qualitative information Fe 2p signal can be extracted since the amount of Co is lower than the iron on the surface. In all samples, can be observed a mixture of Fe2+ (710.3 eV) and Fe3+ (∼712 and ∼715 eV), with the specific satellite of Fe3+ at ∼719 eV [43]. Co 2p high resolution spectra present a Co3O4 footprint, which contains both Co (II) and Co (III). In the series CoFeMox the ratio Co/Fe is in the range 0.3–0.4, while for the series FeCoMox the ratio Co/Fe is found in the range 0.45–0.5. Mo 3d high-resolution spectra evidenced the presence of only one oxidation state Mo6+ [44], which can also be found in cobalt (II) molybdate (CoMoO4) and in iron (II) molybdate (FeMoO4) that were evidenced in the X-ray diffraction patterns. In Table 2 is gathered the surface composition of CoFeMox and FeCoMox. In general, for all samples at the surface the iron is found in a higher amount (∼20 %) than the cobalt (∼9 %). 3.2 Catalytic experiments 3.2.1 Molybdenum loading influence The oxidation of malic acid was carried out at 50 °C, the concentration of malic acid in water being 2 %. Pyruvic acid is the main reaction product, acetic and malonic acid being obtained as secondary products. The catalytic results achieved are illustrated in Fig. 11. Malic acid conversion increased with reaction time and with the molybdenum loading, the catalysts with the FeCoMox formula are more active than those with the CoFeMox formula (Fig. 11 a and 11 b) although the ferrite materials have higher surface areas (see Table 1). The yield of pyruvic acid (Fig. 11 c and 11 d) follows the same trend as the conversion for FeCoMox catalysts with the highest yield in pyruvic acid (more than 40 %) obtained for FeCoMo3 catalyst, while for CoFeMox, it has an inversely proportional variation, the most selective catalysts being CoFeMo1, with a pyruvic acid yield of 48 %. However, the catalysts containing lower loadings of Mo present high yields in pyruvic acid, with values higher than 40 %, higher values than for cobalt-iron mixed oxides catalysts (29 %), presented in our previous study [45], and those obtained by Roostaei et al. [46] in the photocatalytic degradation of lactic acid (20 %) on a two-dimensional (2D) nanosheet-assembled ZnIn2S4 catalyst. Thus, we can infer that the Mo introduction in cobaltite materials brings important changes in catalytic activity, while the introduction of Mo in ferrite materials is more important from the selectivity point of view. In both series of catalysts, the increase in the conversion with the Mo loading can be explained by the presence of O vacancies, as evidenced by X-ray diffraction and XPS analysis, that facilitates the malic acid activation. The presence of iron cobaltite (FeCo2O4) and iron molybdate (FeMoO4) phases leads to an increase in activity compared to cobalt ferrite (CoFe2O4) and cobalt molybdate (CoMoO4) phases ( Scheme 2). The greater activity of the cobaltite type structure compared to the ferrite type was also noticed by Mimani [47] in the decomposition reaction of hydrogen peroxide on Mn and Mg cobaltite and ferrite catalysts. Likewise, Carraro [48] noted that the type FeCo2O4 phase is more active in the oxidative dehydrogenation to acetaldehyde compared to CoFe2O4 one. As reported earlier in one of our studies, a good correlation between malic acid conversion, pyruvic acid yield, and Co content was found, indicating the importance of the Co species for the formation of pyruvic acid [49]. Moreover, in this study, we have noticed the presence of the iron molybdate phase as being benefic for malic acid conversion in the case of cobaltite-based catalyst. Indeed, the higher activity of the iron molybdate phase compared to cobalt molybdate was noticed also by Legendre [50] for propene oxidation to acrolein. For a better understanding of the catalytic activities of the studied catalysts, Fig. 12 a shows the variation of ln(C0/C) in time, where Co is the initial malic acid concentration and C is the concentration at a certain time. The rate constant was determined from the slope of the graph depicted in Fig. 12 a, according to the equation: − dC dt = k ∙ C where: k represents the rate constant and C is malic acid concentration. The values of rate constant are as follows: 2.9·10–3 min−1 (FeCoMo1), 4.1·10–3 min−1 (FeCoMo2), 4.3·10–3 min−1 (FeCoMo3), 2.5·10–3 min−1 (CoFeMo1), 3.7·10–3 min−1 (CoFeMo2) and 4.2·10–3 min−1 (CoFeMo3), respectively. Fig. 12 b presents the variation of rate constant with the ratio between Mo and Fe from EDS, a good correlation being observed, highlighting the influence of molybdenum on the catalytic activity. 3.2.2 Malic acid concentration influence Fig. 13 a presents the variation of malic acid conversion and the product yields as a function of malic acid concentration in water. Both the conversion of malic acid and the yield in pyruvic acid decrease with the increasing of the concentration of MA, indicating that the number of active sites is limited for a certain concentration of reactants. The same variation was observed for the yield in malonic acid, while the yield in acetic acid increased slightly with the concentration of malic acid. 3.2.3 Recyclability test on FeCoMo3 sample To prove the stability of the studied materials, FeCoMo3 sample was subjected to a recyclability test. For this purpose, after the first reaction cycle, the sample was separated by filtration from the reaction medium, washed with distilled water, dried, and calcined before being introduced into the next reaction cycle. This procedure was repeated after the second cycle. On the studied catalyst (Fig. 13 b), the activity remained almost the same in all three reaction cycles. 4 Conclusions Molybdenum doped iron cobaltite and cobalt ferrite samples were prepared by coprecipitation method from iron, cobalt, and molybdenum precursors with ammonia as the precipitating agent. Two phases were reported to be formed for all the samples, FeCo2O4 and FeMoO4 type for FeCoMox and CoFe2O4 and CoMoO4 for CoFeMox. In the second catalyst of each series, most of the molybdenum ions contribute to the formation of the molybdate phase (lattice parameter is decreased), while an expansion of the network, observed for the last catalyst in each series, could be explained by the replacement of cobalt and iron ions with molybdenum, in the cobaltite or ferrite spinels. The Urbach energy values, determined from the UV-Vis spectra, increased with molybdenum loading indicating the formation of a larger number of oxygen vacancies. All the prepared samples were investigated in oxidative decarboxylation of malic acid towards pyruvic acid, a good correlation between molybdenum loading and malic acid conversion being noted for both series. On the other hand, a greater activity of the cobaltite type structure compared to the ferrite type has been observed, maybe due to the formation of a more active iron molybdate phase. CoFeMo based catalysts are stable, recyclable, and easy to separate from the reaction medium, but their limitation consists in controlling the homogeneity of the particle sizes. For instance, the cobaltite tends to agglomerate resulting in higher particle sizes and consequently the smaller specific surface area for these samples. The challenge of these catalysts is related to the improvement of selectivity in pyruvic acid (especially for cobaltite type catalysts) at the expense of selectivity in malonic and acetic acid. coredata.dc:description: In this study, molybdenum doped iron cobaltite and cobalt ferrite catalysts were prepared by coprecipitation, and their structural, morphological, and optical, properties were evaluated by XRD, BET, SEM, FTIR, Raman, XPS and UV–VIS techniques. Their catalytic behavior evaluated in the malic acid oxidative decarboxylation reaction underlined the importance of the incorporation of Mo into the structure of iron cobaltite and cobalt ferrite catalysts. The catalysts with the highest molybdenum content forming cobaltite and iron molybdate phases showed better activity, with cobaltite-based catalysts being more active than ferrite-based ones.
coredata.dc:title: Influence of molybdenum incorporation on the structural, chemical, and catalytic properties of iron cobaltite and cobalt ferrite catalysts
